Interestingly enough, there's actually anywhere between 5 and a-ridiculously-large-amount of cultures that have used the swastika. For instance, in Greek mythology (and no, they actually weren't Western-European, that would be the Romans), it was said to be a firemaker invented by Hermes. In the days of Roman persecution of Christians, it was a modified, simple-to-carve version of the cross used to secretly express one's faith. The Catholic church used it. In any rate, it's been used by quite a few groups in history to express similar, but distinctly less malicious beliefs than Hitler. He just kinda perverted and dang-near completely ruined it.

"Wall Street payed a key role in three significant twentieth-century historical events: the 1917 Lenin-Trotsky Revolution in Russia, the 1933 election of Franklin D. Roosevelt in the United States, and the 1933 seizure of power by Adolf Hitler in Germany. 
Each of these events introduced some variant of socialism into a major country — i.e., Bolshevik socialism in Russia, New Deal socialism in the United States, and National socialism in Germany.
Contemporary academic histories, with perhaps the sole exception of Carroll Quigley's Tragedy And Hope, ignore this evidence. On the other hand, it is understandable that universities and research organizations, dependent on financial aid from foundations that are controlled by this same New York financial elite, would hardly want to support and to publish research on these aspects of international politics. The bravest of trustees is unlikely to bite the hand that feeds his organization."
Anthony C. Sutton in “Wall Street and the rise of Hitler

They never called themselves "Nazis", this word doesn't even really appear in print in Germany until 1945. Before then, it was a Bavarian pejorative term that comes from shortening Ignatius, which had been a commonly used name amongst the rural peasantry, so came to be used to refer to somebody as being backwards, uneducated (a bit like "hillbilly") but this meaning was lost in translation when the name-callers fled Germany and brought the word to the English speaking world. The party renamed to "NSDAP" (as opposed to Hitler's preference, NDAP) as there was an Austrian party of the same name, so they figured doing so would add to the sense of legitimacy (just as they added 500 to party member numbers to make the party seem bigger - making Hitler number 555).

In Spanish, the name Ignatius is shortened to Nacho, which is where the name of the snack comes from... so Nachos and Nazis have this in common!

Also, Hitler wasn't a fascist... just as liberals used the term "Nazi", Socialists used the term "fascist" to refer to many groups of people, like Franco in Spain and Hitler in Germany, which comes from them rejecting the use of a term that associates Hitler with socialism. While Nazis were a grass-roots genuine hate movement, Fascism was a top-down social engineering toolbox that just happened to look the same in many respects, but was very different. Franco wasn't Nazi or Fascist, he was just an ultra right wing conservative/nationalist.
